rsbNotes.title: Ps 77
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 77 An individual prays on behalf of the community (vv. 7–9). A deep lament is followed by eloquent memory of the Exodus.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 77:2
rsbNotes.text: 77:2 my hand is stretched out. A common gesture of prayer was reaching out toward heaven.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 77:5
rsbNotes.text: 77:5 the days of old. The days when God was near and acted to save Israel from its distress.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 77:7
rsbNotes.text: 77:7 spurn. The Lord’s promise to be with His people required their obedience. Though God was longsuffering, at times His patience would run out (1 Sam. 4; Ezek. 9–11; Lamentations).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 77:9
rsbNotes.text: 77:9 Has God forgotten to be gracious. It is impossible that God should cease to be merciful, but the distress of life elicits these questions in the psalmist.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 77:10
rsbNotes.text:
77:10 I will appeal to this. This verse provides a crucial transition in the psalm. By remembering God’s great acts in the past, the poet builds confidence in the present and for the future.

years of the right hand. When God’s power was seen to act for them (Ex. 15:6).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 77:13
rsbNotes.text: 77:13 great. As the writer remembers God’s great acts in the past, he is reminded of God’s attributes: His holiness and His unique power.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 77:15
rsbNotes.text: 77:15 redeemed your people. The context shows that the psalmist has in mind the deliverance of Israel from Egypt.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 77:16
rsbNotes.text: 77:16 waters. In this poetic remembrance of the Exodus, the waters of the Red Sea are personified. In this way the crossing of the Red Sea is pictured as a battle against the waters of chaos (18:4; 29:3, 10; 46:2, 3 and notes).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 77:19
rsbNotes.text: 77:19 your footprints were unseen. God’s action was from above, not controlled by the constraints of earthly conditions.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 77:20
rsbNotes.text: 77:20 You led your people like a flock. The crossing of the Red Sea was a violent conflict; in this verse, the mood is calm as the Shepherd of Israel leads His people through the desert.
